title: Apfel Score for Postoperative Nausea and Vomiting
description: Predicts risk of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) using four simple clinical factors to guide prophylactic antiemetic therapy decisions.

parameters.name: gender
parameters.description: Patient gender (female gender is a risk factor for PONV)

parameters.name: smoking_status
parameters.description: Current smoking status (non-smoking is a risk factor for PONV)

parameters.name: history_motion_sickness_ponv
parameters.description: Previous history of motion sickness or postoperative nausea and vomiting

parameters.name: postoperative_opioids
parameters.description: Planned use of postoperative opioids for pain management

result.name: apfel_score
result.description: Apfel Score for PONV risk assessment (0-4 points)

ranges.interpretation: Approximately 10% risk of PONV within 24 hours. Prophylactic antiemetics generally not recommended.
Approximately 20% risk of PONV within 24 hours. Consider single prophylactic antiemetic agent.
Approximately 40% risk of PONV within 24 hours. Recommend combination of 2 prophylactic antiemetic agents.
Approximately 60% risk of PONV within 24 hours. Recommend combination of 2-3 prophylactic antiemetic agents.
Approximately 80% risk of PONV within 24 hours. Recommend combination of multiple prophylactic antiemetic agents and consider total intravenous anesthesia (TIVA).

references: Apfel CC, Läärä E, Koivuranta M, Greim CA, Roewer N. A simplified risk score for predicting postoperative nausea and vomiting: conclusions from cross-validations between two centers. Anesthesiology. 1999;91(3):693-700.
Gan TJ, Belani KG, Bergese S, et al. Fourth Consensus Guidelines for the Management of Postoperative Nausea and Vomiting. Anesth Analg. 2020;131(2):411-448.
Apfel CC, Heidrich FM, Jukar-Rao S, et al. Evidence-based analysis of risk factors for postoperative nausea and vomiting. Br J Anaesth. 2012;109(5):742-753.
formula: Sum of risk factors: Female gender (1 point) + Non-smoking (1 point) + History of motion sickness or PONV (1 point) + Use of postoperative opioids (1 point)
notes: The Apfel Score is one of the most widely validated and used risk assessment tools for PONV
Each risk factor contributes equally (1 point) to the total score
The score helps guide prophylactic antiemetic therapy decisions in the perioperative period
Consider multimodal prophylaxis for patients with ≥2 risk factors
Total intravenous anesthesia (TIVA) may be considered for very high-risk patients
